WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Sarah Bailey
Address: Prince Albert
Birthplace: Prince County, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1877, married 1897
Where did you set up housekeeping? Prince Albert, Saskatchewan
Where had you been living before that? Initials of children: R.M.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 14 - 35 people
How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? annual, twice a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, coffee, sugar, dried fruits, B. Swan, meat, very occasionally beans, rice, tapioca, eggs, corn starch, currant juice, unsweetened apples, syrup.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Hodgson
Price: 1.25 per lb.
In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 1.25
How much did you use Graham flour?
Whole wheat flour? 10 lbs., brown shortening for stock
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 40 miles
What year? 1877 - 1897
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? 4¢
Whole wheat? 4¢
Farina? 4¢
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Not early enough
How did you grind it?
